resource_name: Global Down Syndrome Foundation - Medical Care Centers Directory
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
service_area_notes: Comprehensive directory of DS clinics by state; last updated May 2025
short_description: Comprehensive online directory of Down syndrome medical care centers across the United States, maintained by Global Down Syndrome Foundation.
full_description: Global Down Syndrome Foundation maintains the most current directory of Down syndrome medical care centers in the US, with a state-by-state interactive map. The directory includes checklist of services provided by each clinic. States with at least one DS specialty clinic are highlighted.
key_features:
• State-by-state clinic directory
• Interactive map
• Service checklists for each clinic
• Regularly updated (last: May 2025)
• Links to adult care guidelines
• AAP Health Supervision guidelines
• Free public access
practical_notes: This is THE primary resource for finding DS specialty clinics. Bookmark this page. States without clinics shown in gray - families in those states may need to travel or use DSC2U telehealth platform.
tags: clinic directory, verified, national, essential resource

resource_name: DSC2U - Down Syndrome Clinic to You
organization_name: Massachusetts General Hospital / Harvard Medical School
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics; Telehealth Services
eligibility_criteria: Caregivers of individuals with Down syndrome
cost_details: Fee varies; some insurance covers; financial assistance available
short_description: Online health tool that generates personalized care plans for individuals with Down syndrome, created by Harvard/MGH experts.
full_description: Down Syndrome Clinic to You (DSC2U) was created by Dr. Brian Skotko and the clinical team at Massachusetts General Hospital to bring DS specialty care to the 95% of families without access to a DS clinic. Caregivers complete an online intake identifying concerns, symptoms, and medical history. The system generates two personalized documents: one for caregivers and one for their primary care provider with customized recommendations based on national guidelines.
key_features:
• Personalized care plans generated instantly
• Two documents: caregiver + PCP version
• Based on national DS guidelines
• Created by MGH/Harvard experts
• Proven effective in clinical trial
• 1.6-fold increase in guideline adherence
• 97% of caregivers found output easy to understand
• 100% of caregivers would recommend to others
• Supported by LuMind IDSC Foundation
practical_notes: This is a game-changer for families without access to DS specialty clinics. The personalized output helps PCPs provide DS-informed care. Complete the intake thoroughly for best results. Some insurance covers the fee.
tags: telehealth, personalized care, Harvard, MGH, essential

subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
address: 8 E 41st St, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10017
short_description: Searchable database of clinical providers with DS specialty services, created by NDSS with its Clinical Advisory Board.
full_description: This database of clinical providers with specialty services for patients with Down syndrome was created by NDSS in partnership with its Clinical Advisory Board. Information was provided by the institutions themselves through surveys. Serves as an informational tool to help families find clinics near them.
key_features:
• Searchable by location
• Verified by institutions
• Clinical Advisory Board oversight
• Find a Clinic feature
• Links to DSC2U for those without local clinics
practical_notes: Use this alongside the Global DS Foundation directory for most complete picture of available clinics. NDSS also operates a national helpline for additional support.

resource_name: Anna and John J. Sie Center for Down Syndrome
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
service_area_notes: One of the leading DS clinics in the United States
lifecycle_stages: PRE, INF, EC, SA, ADO, TA
cost_details: Most insurance accepted; financial assistance available
short_description: One of the leading Down syndrome clinics in the United States, providing world-renowned medical, educational and therapeutic care.
full_description: The Sie Center at Childrens Hospital Colorado is one of the leading DS clinics in the US. Services include evaluation, consultation and therapy for infants, children and teens. They offer prenatal consultation, developmental/behavioral assessment, and treat ADHD, autism, communication, mental health concerns, motor development, feeding, breathing and sleep disorders. Transition services for ages 18-22 help connect to Adult DS Center at Denver Health.
key_features:
• World-renowned DS specialists
• Prenatal consultations
• Comprehensive evaluations
• ADHD and autism expertise
• Feeding and sleep disorder treatment
• Partnership with Linda Crnic Institute
• Partnership with Global DS Foundation
• Transition to adult care at Denver Health
• Groundbreaking clinical research
practical_notes: This is one of the premier DS clinics in the country. Families travel from across the Rocky Mountain region. Connected to cutting-edge research through Crnic Institute. Adults over 22 should transition to Denver Health Adult DS Center.
tags: premier clinic, Rocky Mountain, research, comprehensive

resource_name: Down Syndrome Program at Boston Childrens Hospital
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
states_available: MA, NH, VT, ME, RI, CT
service_area_notes: Founded 1967 - one of oldest and largest DS programs
short_description: One of the oldest and largest DS programs in the nation, providing specialized healthcare since 1967.
full_description: Founded in 1967, the Down Syndrome Program at Boston Childrens is one of the oldest and largest of its kind. Uses interdisciplinary clinical approach working with subspecialists. Offers innovative behavioral, neurodevelopmental, and neuropsychological evaluations to individualize therapies and educational interventions. Provides intensive care coordination, resource specialists, workshops, support groups, and Allen C. Crocker Speaker Series webinars.
key_features:
• Founded 1967 - 55+ years experience
• Interdisciplinary approach
• Neurodevelopmental evaluations
• Neuropsychological assessments
• Care coordination
• Resource specialists
• Parent workshops and support groups
• Free webinar series
• Research through Cognitive Neuroscience Labs
• Translational Neuroscience Center partnership
practical_notes: One of the most established DS programs in the country. The Allen C. Crocker Speaker Series webinars are free and available online - excellent resource even for families not seen at this clinic.

resource_name: Down Syndrome Program at Massachusetts General Hospital
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
states_available: MA, NH, VT, ME, RI, CT
service_area_notes: Four distinct clinics for different age groups; created DSC2U
short_description: Comprehensive Down syndrome program with four distinct clinics for different age groups, creators of DSC2U telehealth platform.
full_description: MGHs DS Program has four distinct clinics ensuring age-specific specialty care: Early Childhood, School-Age, Transition, and Adult. Provides prenatal consultations for expectant parents with prenatal diagnosis. Created the DSC2U platform to extend expertise nationally. Led by Dr. Brian Skotko, internationally recognized DS expert.
key_features:
• Four age-specific clinics
• Prenatal consultations available
• Lifespan care (all ages)
• Created DSC2U platform
• Led by Dr. Brian Skotko
• Harvard Medical School affiliation
• Research programs
• Transition planning services
• Adult health expertise
practical_notes: MGH created DSC2U, so families seen here get the same expertise that powers the telehealth platform. One of few programs with true lifespan care including adult clinic.
tags: lifespan care, DSC2U creators, Harvard, adults

subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
service_area_notes: First and largest adult DS clinic in US; established 1992
eligibility_criteria: Down syndrome diagnosis; age 12+; currently accepting IL residents
cost_details: Accepts most insurance including Medicare and Medicaid
short_description: The first and largest clinic for adolescents and adults with Down syndrome in the United States, established in 1992.
full_description: Established in 1992, the Adult Down Syndrome Center was the first and remains the largest clinic for adolescents and adults with DS in the US. Part of Advocate Health, located at Lutheran General Hospital campus. Led by Dr. Brian Chicoine, co-author of "Guide to Good Health for Teens and Adults with Down Syndrome." Selected as Center of Excellence for DS Clinical Trials Network. Features extensive free online Resource Library.
key_features:
• First adult DS clinic in US (est. 1992)
• Largest adult DS clinic nationally
• Serves ages 12+
• Led by Dr. Brian Chicoine
• Center of Excellence - DS Clinical Trials Network
• Extensive online Resource Library (free)
• Accepts Medicare/Medicaid
• Awards from NDSC, DSMIG, IL Academy of Family Physicians
• CARE Down Syndrome educational initiative for providers
practical_notes: This is THE adult DS clinic in the US - decades of expertise with adult health issues. Their free online Resource Library at adscresources.advocatehealth.com is invaluable even for families not seen here. Currently accepting IL residents age 12+.
tags: adult care, oldest program, Dr. Chicoine, essential resource

resource_name: Down Syndrome Clinic at Childrens National Hospital
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
service_area_notes: Only dedicated DS clinic in Washington DC metro area
short_description: The only dedicated Down syndrome clinic in the Washington, D.C. metropolitan area.
full_description: Childrens National has the only dedicated DS clinic in the DC metro area. The clinic is coordinated through the Rare Disease Institute. Multidisciplinary team provides comprehensive care for physical, mental and emotional health. Offers prenatal consultations through Fetal Institute. Sees babies, children and adults throughout their lifetime. First visit recommended within 3 months of birth.
key_features:
• Only DS clinic in DC metro
• Part of Rare Disease Institute
• Prenatal consultations via Fetal Institute
• Lifespan care (all ages)
• Multidisciplinary team
• Geneticist on team
• Child development specialists
• Community resource connections
• Parent education materials
• Culturally sensitive assistance
practical_notes: Key resource for families in DC, Virginia, and Maryland. Recommend first visit within 3 months of birth. Coordinates with Fetal Institute for prenatal diagnosis support.

resource_name: Down Syndrome Clinic at Phoenix Childrens Hospital
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
service_area_notes: Part of Barrow Neurological Institute at Phoenix Childrens
lifecycle_stages: PRE, INF, EC, SA, ADO, TA
cost_details: Most insurance including AHCCCS (AZ Medicaid) accepted
short_description: Comprehensive DS evaluations led by board-certified developmental pediatrician, part of renowned Barrow Neurological Institute.
full_description: The Down Syndrome Clinic at Phoenix Childrens is led by a board-certified developmental and behavioral pediatrician. Offers comprehensive evaluations focusing on highlighting abilities while providing support. Part of Barrow Neurological Institute, connecting with experts across specialties. Develops unique personalized care plans. Offers prenatal consultations for families with prenatal diagnosis. Actively engaged in research.
key_features:
• Board-certified developmental pediatrician
• Part of Barrow Neurological Institute
• Comprehensive evaluations
• Prenatal consultations
• Personalized care plans
• Multi-specialty connections
• Research participation
• Accepts AHCCCS (Medicaid)
practical_notes: Key resource for Arizona and Southwest families. Connection to Barrow Neurological Institute provides access to top neurological expertise. Offers prenatal consultations.

resource_name: Down Syndrome Clinic at Nationwide Childrens Hospital
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
service_area_notes: Family-centered clinic with online scheduling via MyChart
short_description: Family-centered clinic providing diagnostic and treatment services, linking families with community resources.
full_description: The Down Syndrome Clinic at Nationwide Childrens is family-centered, providing diagnostic and treatment services. Links families with medical, educational, social and financial supports. Team includes developmental pediatricians, psychologists, geneticists, and advanced practice nurses who maintain close relationship with childs PCP. Offers ADHD and Autism assessments, behavior management counseling, and recommended health supervision screening.
key_features:
• Family-centered approach
• ADHD and autism assessments
• Behavior management counseling
• Health supervision screening
• Community resource connections
• Educational and social supports
• Financial support navigation
• Online scheduling via MyChart
• Close PCP coordination
practical_notes: Good option for Ohio families. Strong focus on connecting families with community resources beyond medical care. Can schedule follow-ups through MyChart.

resource_name: Down Syndrome Specialty Clinic at University of Washington
organization_name: University of Washington - IHDD Clinical Training Unit
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
address: University of Washington Medical Center, Seattle, WA
service_area_notes: Part of IHDD Clinical Training Unit; interpreter services available
short_description: DS specialty clinic at UW, led by developmental behavioral pediatrician, with interpreter services available.
full_description: The Down Syndrome Specialty Clinic is part of the IHDD (Institute on Human Development and Disability) Clinical Training Unit at University of Washington Medical Center. Led by Emily Myers, MD, Developmental Behavioral Pediatrician. Uses MyChart for appointments and health records. Medical interpreters available for families who do not speak English.
key_features:
• University of Washington expertise
• Developmental Behavioral Pediatrician
• MyChart access for records
• Interpreter services in multiple languages
• IHDD affiliation
• Training center
practical_notes: Key resource for Pacific Northwest families including Alaska. Request interpreter services in advance if needed.

resource_name: Center for Down Syndrome at Lucile Packard Childrens Hospital Stanford
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
service_area_notes: One of few childrens hospitals offering comprehensive DS services
short_description: Comprehensive DS program at Stanford helping children reach full potential and function independently.
full_description: The Center for Down Syndrome at Lucile Packard Childrens Hospital Stanford helps each child with Down Syndrome reach full potential and function as independently as possible in all aspects of school and family life. One of few childrens hospitals in the nation to offer these comprehensive services.
key_features:
• Stanford/Packard expertise
• Comprehensive services
• Full potential focus
• Independence skills
• School support
• Family life integration
• Medi-Cal accepted
practical_notes: Excellent option for Northern California families. Stanford affiliation means access to cutting-edge research and top specialists.

resource_name: Down Syndrome Clinic at Kennedy Krieger Institute
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
lifecycle_stages: INF, EC, SA, ADO, TA, YA
short_description: Internationally recognized center helping individuals with DS reach full potential in family, school and community life.
full_description: Kennedy Krieger Institutes Down Syndrome Clinic team helps each individual with Down Syndrome reach full potential and function as independently as possible in all aspects of family, school and community life. Part of the internationally renowned Kennedy Krieger Institute, affiliated with Johns Hopkins.
key_features:
• Johns Hopkins affiliation
• Internationally recognized
• Full potential focus
• Independence skills
• Family support
• School integration
• Community participation
• Research opportunities
practical_notes: Kennedy Krieger is world-renowned for developmental disabilities. Excellent option for Mid-Atlantic families. Strong in neurodevelopmental assessment and behavioral services.

resource_name: GiGis Playhouse - FREE Down Syndrome Achievement Centers
subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy; Occupational Therapy; Physical Therapy
states_available: AZ, AR, CA, CO, FL, GA, IL, IN, IA, LA, MD, MI, MN, NV, NJ, NY, NC, ND, OH, OR, PA, SC, TN, TX, UT, WA, WI + Mexico
service_area_notes: 61+ brick-and-mortar locations; Virtual Playhouse available worldwide
short_description: The ONLY international network of Down Syndrome Achievement Centers providing 100% FREE therapeutic, educational and career programs at 61+ locations.
full_description: GiGis Playhouse is the only network of Down Syndrome Achievement Centers, with 61+ brick-and-mortar locations across the US and Mexico, plus a Virtual Playhouse serving families worldwide. Every program is FREE - always. Programs include speech therapy, literacy tutoring, math tutoring, GiGiFIT physical fitness, occupational therapy, career development, and more. In 2025, on track to provide over 350,000 hours of free programming. Founded by Nancy Gianni, with GiGi Gianni serving as Chief Inspiration Officer.
key_features:
• 100% FREE - always
• 61+ locations in 27+ states + Mexico
• Virtual Playhouse for remote families
• Speech therapy programs
• One-on-one literacy tutoring
• One-on-one math tutoring
• GiGiFIT physical fitness
• Career development programs
• All ages - prenatal through adult
• 350,000+ hours of programming annually
• Volunteer-powered
• New locations opening regularly
practical_notes: This is THE essential free resource for DS families. Every family should check if there is a GiGis near them. Even if no local Playhouse, Virtual Playhouse offers one-on-one tutoring. Programs are therapeutic but delivered in fun, supportive environment. Sign up early as popular programs have waitlists.
tags: FREE, essential resource, therapy, education, all ages, nationwide

subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy; Occupational Therapy; Physical Therapy
short_description: FREE Down Syndrome Achievement Center in Chicago offering therapeutic and educational programs.
full_description: GiGis Playhouse Chicago provides FREE therapeutic, educational and career programs for individuals with Down syndrome. Programs include speech therapy, literacy tutoring, math tutoring, GiGiFIT fitness, and more.
key_features:
• 100% FREE
• All ages served
• Speech therapy
• Literacy tutoring
• Math tutoring
• GiGiFIT fitness
• Social programs
practical_notes: Contact local Playhouse for program schedule and availability.

practical_notes: Contact local Playhouse for program schedule and availability.

subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy; Telehealth Services
short_description: FREE virtual one-on-one tutoring serving families worldwide across 6 continents.
full_description: GiGis Virtual Playhouse provides FREE one-on-one tutoring programs via video conferencing, making GiGis programs accessible to families worldwide. Serves families across 6 continents. Programs include literacy tutoring, math tutoring, and speech skills (Amina Grace program).
key_features:
• 100% FREE
• Serves 6 continents
• One-on-one tutoring
• Literacy programs
• Math programs
• Amina Grace speech program
• Video-based sessions
practical_notes: Essential resource for families not near a physical Playhouse location. Register through virtual playhouse website.

subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy; Feeding/Swallowing Therapy
service_area_notes: Products and training available worldwide; therapist locator
cost_details: Products range $10-$500+; therapy costs vary by provider
short_description: Oral Placement Therapy tools and training developed by Sara Rosenfeld-Johnson, particularly effective for Down syndrome.
full_description: TalkTools provides Oral Placement Therapy (OPT) tools, training courses, and resources. Founded by Sara Rosenfeld-Johnson, MS, CCC-SLP, who identified the "oral-motor myths of Down syndrome" and developed tactile-proprioceptive approaches particularly effective for DS. Products include the Horn Hierarchy, Straw Hierarchy, Bite Blocks, feeding tools, and sensory products. Offers CEU training for SLPs and OTs. Therapist locator available.
key_features:
• Oral Placement Therapy approach
• Founded by Sara Rosenfeld-Johnson
• DS-specific expertise
• Horn and Straw Hierarchies
• Bite Blocks for jaw stability
• Feeding therapy tools
• Sensory tools
• CEU courses for therapists
• Therapist locator
• ASHA and AOTA CEUs
practical_notes: Many SLPs use TalkTools with DS clients. Ask your SLP if they are trained in OPT. The straw and horn hierarchies are popular for addressing tongue retraction and lip strength. Can purchase tools directly or find a TalkTools-trained therapist.
tags: oral motor, OPT, tools, Sara Rosenfeld-Johnson, feeding

subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy
service_area_notes: iOS app (iPad, iPhone, Mac, Apple Watch)
short_description: Gold standard AAC app used by people with Down syndrome, autism, cerebral palsy worldwide.
full_description: Proloquo2Go is recognized as the gold standard in AAC (Augmentative and Alternative Communication) apps. Symbol-based communication app with natural-sounding voices including childrens voices. Features Crescendo vocabulary with consistent core word placement supporting motor planning. Used by people with Down syndrome, autism, cerebral palsy, Angelman syndrome. Available in English, Spanish, French, Dutch with bilingual support. Fully customizable for all skill levels.
key_features:
• Gold standard AAC app
• Used widely with Down syndrome
• 100+ natural voices including children
• Crescendo core word vocabulary
• Motor planning support
• Customizable for all levels
• 10,000+ fringe words
• Multiple languages
• Works on iPad, iPhone, Mac, Watch
• 7-day/week support
practical_notes: While expensive compared to typical apps, Proloquo2Go is a fraction of dedicated AAC device costs ($5,000+). Many families get insurance to cover cost through AAC funding - contact AbleNet for funding support. Works offline once downloaded.

subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy
service_area_notes: Official directory of certified SLPs and audiologists
short_description: Official ASHA directory to find certified speech-language pathologists by location and specialty.
full_description: ASHA ProFind is the official searchable directory of ASHA-certified speech-language pathologists and audiologists. Search by location, specialty area (pediatrics, feeding, AAC, etc.), and other criteria. Verifies CCC-SLP certification.
key_features:
• Official ASHA directory
• Searchable by location
• Filter by specialty
• Verify credentials
• Find pediatric specialists
• Find feeding specialists
• Find AAC specialists
• Free to search
practical_notes: Use this to find SLPs and verify credentials. Filter for pediatric specialty. When contacting therapists, specifically ask about Down syndrome experience - not all pediatric SLPs have DS expertise.

subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy; Telehealth Services
short_description: Online speech therapy platform with Down syndrome speech therapy specialty page.
full_description: Better Speech provides online speech therapy services with licensed SLPs. Features specific information about Down syndrome speech therapy on their website. Offers flexible scheduling and accepts various insurance plans.
key_features:
• Online speech therapy
• DS-specific content
• Licensed SLPs
• Insurance accepted
• Flexible scheduling
• All ages
practical_notes: Telehealth option for families without local DS-experienced SLPs. Verify therapist has DS experience when booking.

organization_name: Down Syndrome Association of Central Texas
subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy
eligibility_criteria: DS diagnosis; ages 4-25; able to focus and remain seated
short_description: Parents Empowering Articulation in Kids - 18-month speech therapy program designed for DS communication challenges.
full_description: DSACT PEAK (Parents Empowering Articulation in Kids) is an 18-month program addressing unique communication challenges faced by individuals with Down syndrome. Requires parent/caregiver attendance and homework commitment. Located at DSACT office in Austin.
key_features:
• 18-month program
• DS-specific approach
• Parent involvement required
• Ages 4-25
• Scholarship funding
• Austin-based
practical_notes: Registration opens periodically - check website. Parent must attend sessions and do homework between sessions. May be able to get some insurance reimbursement for out-of-network.

subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy
service_area_notes: Multiple AAC apps for different needs
cost_details: Various apps at different price points
short_description: Suite of AAC apps including Proloquo2Go, Proloquo, and Proloquo4Text for different communication needs.
full_description: AssistiveWare develops multiple AAC apps: Proloquo2Go (symbol-based, highly customizable), Proloquo (newer symbol-based with vast vocabulary), Proloquo4Text (text-to-speech for literate users), and Pictello (visual stories). Offers Learn AAC resources, Core Word Classroom activities, and professional licenses for SLPs.
key_features:
• Multiple app options
• Proloquo2Go - customizable AAC
• Proloquo - newer symbol-based
• Proloquo4Text - text-based
• Learn AAC resources
• Core Word Classroom
• Professional licenses available
• 7-day support
practical_notes: Use their product guide questionnaire to find which app fits your needs. Professional licenses available free for qualifying SLPs/OTs.

subcategories: Medical Specialists
address: 8 E 41st St, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10017
short_description: Leading national advocacy organization with healthcare provider database, helpline, and comprehensive resources.
key_features:
• National helpline 800-221-4602
• Healthcare provider database
• Educational resources
• Policy advocacy
• Local affiliate network
practical_notes: Call the helpline for help finding healthcare providers in your area.

subcategories: Medical Specialists
short_description: National organization providing healthcare resources, annual convention, and state affiliate network.
key_features:
• Annual convention
• DS clinic directory
• Healthcare resources
• State affiliate network
• Advocacy
practical_notes: NDSC convention is the largest DS-focused event annually with healthcare sessions.

subcategories: Medical Specialists
service_area_notes: Research funding; DSC2U support; Clinical Trials Network
short_description: Research-focused organization supporting DSC2U, Clinical Trials Network, and breakthrough therapies.
key_features:
• Founding supporter of DSC2U
• DS Clinical Trials Network
• Research funding
• Cognition research focus
• Community support
practical_notes: Key organization funding DS research. Supports DSC2U accessibility.

resource_name: IDEA Part C Early Intervention (Birth to 3)
organization_name: US Department of Education / State Lead Agencies
subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy; Occupational Therapy; Physical Therapy
service_area_notes: Federal entitlement; administered by each state
eligibility_criteria: Down syndrome automatically qualifies in most states
cost_details: 100% FREE to families regardless of income
short_description: FREE federally-mandated therapy services (PT, OT, speech, special instruction) for children birth to 3 with disabilities.
full_description: IDEA Part C Early Intervention is a federal entitlement providing FREE therapy services to infants and toddlers with disabilities from birth to age 3. Down syndrome automatically qualifies in most states. Services typically include speech therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, special instruction, and family training - all at no cost regardless of income.
key_features:
• 100% FREE to all families
• DS auto-qualifies
• Speech, OT, PT, special instruction
• Home-based services
• Family training included
• No income limits
• Federal entitlement
• Worth $30,000-$100,000+/year value
practical_notes: Contact your state EI program immediately after diagnosis - services can start within weeks of birth. The earlier you start, the better outcomes. This is the single most valuable program for babies with DS.

resource_name: Special Olympics Healthy Athletes - Opening Eyes
subcategories: Vision/Hearing Services
service_area_notes: Free screenings at Special Olympics events
lifecycle_stages: SA, ADO, TA, YA, MA, OA
short_description: FREE comprehensive vision screenings and prescription eyeglasses at Special Olympics events.
full_description: Opening Eyes provides free comprehensive vision screenings and prescription eyeglasses to Special Olympics athletes at competitions and events. Over 60% of people with DS have vision problems. The program identifies vision issues and provides free high-quality glasses.
key_features:
• 100% FREE
• Comprehensive screenings
• Prescription glasses provided
• At Special Olympics events
• Eye health education
practical_notes: If participating in Special Olympics, take advantage of Opening Eyes at events. Vision problems often go undetected in people with DS.

resource_name: Special Olympics Healthy Athletes - Healthy Hearing
subcategories: Vision/Hearing Services
service_area_notes: Free screenings at Special Olympics events
lifecycle_stages: SA, ADO, TA, YA, MA, OA
short_description: FREE hearing screenings at Special Olympics events - crucial for DS population where 75%+ have hearing loss.
full_description: Healthy Hearing provides free hearing screenings to Special Olympics athletes. Up to 75% of individuals with Down syndrome have hearing loss, which impacts speech/language development and learning. The program identifies hearing problems and provides referrals for follow-up care.
key_features:
• 100% FREE
• Hearing screenings
• At Special Olympics events
• Referrals provided
• Critical for DS population
practical_notes: Hearing loss is extremely common in DS and often goes undetected. Get regular hearing checks.

resource_name: Adult Down Syndrome Center Resource Library
organization_name: Advocate Health - Adult Down Syndrome Center
subcategories: Medical Specialists
short_description: FREE comprehensive online resource library covering physical and mental health topics for teens and adults with DS.
full_description: The Adult Down Syndrome Center maintains an extensive FREE online Resource Library covering a broad range of physical and psychosocial health topics for adolescents and adults with Down syndrome. Created by experts at the nations largest adult DS clinic.
key_features:
• 100% FREE
• Physical health topics
• Mental health topics
• Adult-focused
• Expert-created
• Comprehensive coverage
practical_notes: Essential bookmark for families with teens/adults with DS. Contains expert guidance on adult health issues many PCPs are unfamiliar with.
tags: FREE, adult, resource library, Dr. Chicoine

subcategories: Feeding/Swallowing Therapy
short_description: National organization for pediatric feeding disorders with provider directory and resources.
full_description: Feeding Matters is the leading national organization dedicated to pediatric feeding disorders. Provides education, advocacy, and provider directory. Many children with Down syndrome experience feeding difficulties due to low muscle tone.
key_features:
• Provider directory
• Family resources
• Professional education
• Advocacy
• Support community
practical_notes: Feeding challenges are common in DS. Feeding Matters helps find specialists and provides support.

resource_name: Dental Lifeline Network - Donated Dental Services
subcategories: Dental Care
eligibility_criteria: Low income with disability or age 65+
cost_details: Free donated dental care for those who qualify
short_description: FREE comprehensive dental care for people with disabilities who cannot afford treatment.
full_description: Dental Lifeline Networks Donated Dental Services program provides free comprehensive dental care to people with disabilities who cannot afford treatment. Volunteer dentists donate time and skills. Valuable for adults with DS who often lack dental insurance.
key_features:
• FREE dental care
• Volunteer dentists
• Comprehensive treatment
• Disabilities served
• All 50 states
• Waitlist may apply
practical_notes: Apply early - there may be waitlists. Treatment is comprehensive once accepted. Important for adults with DS who often have limited income and no dental insurance.

subcategories: Medical Specialists
service_area_notes: NIH-run registry connecting families with research
short_description: NIH registry connecting DS families with research opportunities.
full_description: DS-Connect is a secure online registry that connects families with research studies. Maintained by NIH/NICHD. Registering can provide access to clinical trials and helps advance DS research.
key_features:
• NIH registry
• Connect with research
• Secure platform
• Free to join
• Advance DS science
practical_notes: Register to be notified of research opportunities. Contributing to research helps all families.

subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy; Occupational Therapy; Physical Therapy
address: 141 W. Jackson Blvd, Suite 1400A, Chicago, IL 60604
service_area_notes: 70+ affiliates nationwide; services vary by location
cost_details: Accepts Medicaid, insurance, sliding scale available at many locations
short_description: National network of 70+ affiliates providing pediatric therapy (PT, OT, speech), early intervention, and disability services.
full_description: Easterseals is a national nonprofit with over 70 affiliates providing comprehensive services to people with disabilities. Pediatric programs include physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech-language therapy, early intervention, feeding therapy, and specialized programs. Many locations accept Medicaid, CHIP, and offer sliding scale fees. Services vary by location.
key_features:
• 70+ affiliate locations
• PT, OT, speech therapy
• Early intervention services
• Feeding therapy
• Accepts Medicaid/CHIP at many locations
• Sliding scale fees often available
• Ages birth-21 typically
• Family-centered approach
practical_notes: Search for your local Easterseals on their website - services vary significantly by location. Many locations serve children with DS and accept Medicaid. Ask about sliding scale if cost is a concern.
tags: therapy network, Medicaid, sliding scale, nationwide

organization_name: The Arc of the United States
subcategories: Medical Specialists
address: 1825 K Street NW, Suite 1200, Washington, DC 20006
eligibility_criteria: People with intellectual and developmental disabilities
cost_details: Services vary by chapter; many free or subsidized
short_description: Largest national organization serving people with IDD, with ~577 chapters providing advocacy, services, and supports.
full_description: The Arc is the nations largest organization serving people with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Founded in 1950 by parents, The Arc has approximately 577 chapters in 49 states. Local chapters provide a wide variety of services including advocacy, residential services, vocational services, day programs, recreation, family support, and resource navigation. Services help families navigate healthcare, education, and community inclusion.
key_features:
• ~577 chapters nationwide
• Advocacy services
• Residential services
• Vocational programs
• Family support
• Resource navigation
• Founded 1950
• State and local chapters
practical_notes: Find your local Arc chapter for help navigating disability services, finding resources, and advocacy support. The Arc can help connect you with healthcare providers, therapy services, and community programs.

resource_name: Down Syndrome Clinic and Research Center at Kennedy Krieger
subcategories: DS Specialty Clinics
states_available: MD, VA, DC, PA, DE, and nationwide
service_area_notes: Sees patients from all over US; affiliated with Johns Hopkins
short_description: Interdisciplinary DS clinic providing comprehensive evaluations from birth to adulthood, with integrated clinical research.
full_description: The Down Syndrome Clinic and Research Center at Kennedy Krieger provides interdisciplinary and comprehensive evaluations and treatment services from birth to adulthood. Specializes in cognitive and neurobehavioral dysfunction, mental health, sleep medicine, and behavioral interventions. Clinical research programs directly inform patient care and therapy development. Affiliated with Johns Hopkins.
key_features:
• Birth to adulthood care
• Interdisciplinary team
• Johns Hopkins affiliated
• Clinical research programs
• Neurobehavioral expertise
• Sleep medicine
• Mental health services
• Clinical trials available
• Hannah Rose Culotta Research Fund
practical_notes: Kennedy Krieger is internationally recognized for neurodevelopmental expertise. They see patients from across the US. Clinical research opportunities available.

organization_name: Professional Association of Therapeutic Horsemanship International
subcategories: Physical Therapy; Occupational Therapy
service_area_notes: 800+ member centers; find centers via website
short_description: Network of 800+ therapeutic riding centers offering hippotherapy and equine-assisted activities for people with disabilities.
full_description: PATH International is the credentialing organization for therapeutic horseback riding and hippotherapy. Over 800 member centers nationwide offer equine-assisted activities for people with disabilities including Down syndrome. Benefits include improved core strength, balance, coordination, sensory integration, and confidence. Many centers offer scholarships.
key_features:
• 800+ accredited centers
• Hippotherapy (PT/OT on horseback)
• Therapeutic riding
• Improves core strength and balance
• Sensory integration benefits
• Confidence building
• Many offer scholarships
• Find centers on website
practical_notes: Many children with DS benefit greatly from hippotherapy - the horse movement provides unique sensory and motor input. Search PATH website for accredited centers near you. Ask about scholarships.
tags: hippotherapy, therapeutic riding, horses, PT, OT

subcategories: Medical Specialists
eligibility_criteria: New or expectant parents receiving DS diagnosis
short_description: FREE peer support and resource connection for families receiving a new or prenatal Down syndrome diagnosis.
full_description: The Down Syndrome Diagnosis Network provides free peer support to families at the time of diagnosis. Trained parent volunteers connect with new families to provide accurate information, emotional support, and resource connections. Helps ensure families have positive, accurate information when receiving a DS diagnosis.
key_features:
• FREE support
• Peer parent volunteers
• Prenatal and postnatal support
• Accurate information
• Resource connections
• Emotional support
• 100+ first calls/month
practical_notes: Essential resource for newly diagnosed families. Connect immediately after diagnosis for support and guidance from experienced parents.
tags: new parents, diagnosis, peer support, FREE

subcategories: Physical Therapy; Occupational Therapy; Speech-Language Therapy
address: Los Angeles, CA; Boston, MA; Denver, CO; Austin, TX; Sydney, Australia
service_area_notes: Intensive therapy model - families travel for 2-4 week sessions
eligibility_criteria: Children with neurological and developmental conditions
short_description: Intensive pediatric therapy (2-4 hours daily for 2-4 weeks) producing accelerated gains for children with disabilities.
full_description: NAPA Center offers intensive pediatric therapy sessions where children receive 2-4+ hours of combined PT, OT, and speech therapy daily for 2-4 weeks. This intensive model can produce significant gains in shorter timeframes than traditional weekly therapy. Multiple US locations plus international. Offers scholarships - apply through their website.
key_features:
• Intensive therapy model
• 2-4 hours daily
• 2-4 week sessions
• PT, OT, speech combined
• Multiple US locations
• Scholarships available
• Specialized equipment
• DS expertise
practical_notes: Many families report dramatic gains from NAPA intensives. Apply for scholarships - they award significant funding. Families often combine with vacation. Plan housing and travel in advance.

organization_name: Childhood Apraxia of Speech Association of North America
subcategories: Speech-Language Therapy
service_area_notes: Resources and provider directory for childhood apraxia of speech
eligibility_criteria: Children with CAS or suspected CAS
cost_details: Free resources; paid trainings for professionals
short_description: Leading organization for childhood apraxia of speech (CAS), common in Down syndrome, with provider directory and family resources.
full_description: Apraxia Kids is the leading nonprofit for childhood apraxia of speech (CAS). Many children with Down syndrome have motor speech components that may include apraxia. The organization provides family resources, professional training, and a directory of SLPs trained in motor speech treatment approaches like DTTC.
key_features:
• CAS resources
• Provider directory
• Professional training
• Family support
• Research information
• Motor speech expertise
• DTTC training
practical_notes: If your child with DS has speech that is hard to understand despite therapy, ask about motor speech/apraxia evaluation. Apraxia Kids can help find appropriately trained SLPs.
tags: apraxia, motor speech, CAS, SLP directory

subcategories: Physical Therapy; Occupational Therapy
address: 1825 K Street NW, Suite 600, Washington, DC 20006
service_area_notes: Network of affiliates; services vary by location
eligibility_criteria: People with disabilities (not limited to CP)
cost_details: Services and costs vary by affiliate
short_description: National network providing therapy, early intervention, and disability services (serves all disabilities, not just CP).
full_description: United Cerebral Palsy is a national network providing services to people with all types of disabilities, not just cerebral palsy. Local affiliates may offer therapy services, early intervention, day programs, residential services, and advocacy. Services vary significantly by location.
key_features:
• National affiliate network
• Serves all disabilities
• Therapy services at some locations
• Early intervention
• Advocacy
• Community programs
practical_notes: Despite the name, UCP serves people with all disabilities including DS. Search for local affiliate - services vary significantly by location.

subcategories: Vision/Hearing Services
eligibility_criteria: Infants ages 6-12 months; no income requirements
short_description: FREE comprehensive eye exam for infants ages 6-12 months - critical for DS babies who have high rates of vision problems.
full_description: InfantSEE is a public health program providing free comprehensive eye assessments for infants between 6-12 months. Participating optometrists provide the service at no cost regardless of family income or insurance. Especially important for babies with Down syndrome who have high rates of vision issues.
key_features:
• 100% FREE
• Ages 6-12 months
• Comprehensive exam
• No income requirements
• Find providers on website
• Critical for DS babies
practical_notes: All babies should have an eye exam in the first year, but its especially critical for DS babies. 60%+ will have vision issues. Find a participating provider at infantsee.org.

resource_name: Lions Club - Vision and Hearing Programs
subcategories: Vision/Hearing Services
cost_details: Free eyeglasses and hearing aids for those in need
short_description: Lions Clubs provide FREE eyeglasses, hearing aids, and vision/hearing screenings to those in need.
full_description: Lions Clubs International has made sight and hearing preservation a primary focus. Local clubs provide free eyeglasses, hearing aids, and screenings to those who cannot afford them. Contact your local Lions Club for assistance.
key_features:
• Free eyeglasses
• Free hearing aids
• Vision screenings
• Hearing screenings
• Local clubs
• Income-based assistance
practical_notes: If you need help affording glasses or hearing aids, contact your local Lions Club. Programs vary by location.
tags: FREE, glasses, hearing aids, low income
